section.title: Monitoring &SHORT_PLATFORM_NAME; with SNMP
section.para: Any System and Application Administrator will not truly feel at ease without knowing what is going on with his servers. The same thing goes for those who have to manage an application server like &SHORT_PLATFORM_NAME; in a production environment. You need to be able to get an overview of what is going on in order to proactively fix issues before you get a phone call from users. With this in mind, the Simple Network Management Protocol was developed (SNMP). The fact that it says simple, doesnâ€™t mean it is simplistic. The protocol is very comprehensive and it has become an industry standard through it's many iterations.

formalpara.title: Understanding SNMP
formalpara.para: It is important to understand that SNMP is not just an application monitoring protocol but comprehensive network protocol that can be configured to keep an eye on both hardware and software. That means that an Administrator can get an overview of all the components on a local and remote network from a single interface. There are a few things that must be defined in order to get a working understanding of how SNMP can help you monitor &PLATFORM_NAME;. There are three important components to understand:

seglistitem.seg: These are applications like &SHORT_PLATFORM_NAME; and devices like routers, switches, UPS, etc..
Software that runs on Managed devices. Agents gather information about the local system and send it to the Manager (NMS). It acts as an intermediate between the Managed devices and the Manager (NMS)

This is the central application from which the System/Network Administrator will interact with all the managed devices. Some common Network Managed Systems (NMS) applications are Zenoss, OpenNMS, Nagios, SNMPC, HPOpenView, PRTG, OpManager, etc.

formalpara.title: SNMP Versions
formalpara.para: There are 3 versions that are currently in use in the SNMP protocol framework. From version 1 to the current version 3, improvements have been made to the protocol to make it more robust and suitable for enterprise use, providing cryptographic security. Version 3 is of particular interest in &SHORT_PLATFORM_NAME; scheme because it provides for better security. SNMP version 3 offers a form of security that requires a username, password and MD5, SHA authentication protocols to safely interact with Managed Devices. This is a better security layer than the Community String password that was used in previous versions. It is still possible to use all three versions simultanously depending on your current system configuration.

formalpara.title: SNMP Object Identifier (OID)
formalpara.para:
An OID is a set of variables that uniquely identifiers Managed objects in a Management Information Base (MIB) within the SNMP protocol framework. An OID hierachy looks like the following:
ISO(1).Orginazation(3).Department of Defense(6).Internet(1).Private(4).Enterprises(1).Redhat(2132).JBOSS(100).Application Server(1)
Another form of presenting the above OID is as follows:
1.3.6.1.4.1.2132.100.1
SNMP OID Hierarchy

formalpara.title: Management Information Base (MIB)
formalpara.para: The MIB in SNMP defines a list of variables that describe specific information about managed devices. An example will be a MIB variable that measures the temparature of a network device. This temperature sensor variable can later be exposed to the Manager(NMS) through the SNMP Agent. The variables in a MIB are organized in a hierarchy that makes accessing needed information easier. The variables in a MIB are presented in two forms, Scalar and Tabular.

listitem.para: Scalar - These are variables that can only hold a single value at a time and are not part of an array or a table
Tabular - These variables have multiple related object instances and can be identified by the index value in a MIB table or array.

section.para: You don't have to worry overtly about the difference as you will become familiar with them the more you work with SNMP.

formalpara.title: SNMP Protocol Data Unit (PDU)
formalpara.para:
PDUs can be seen as packets used to interact with objects within the scope of SNMP. There are 7 available PDUs as of version 3 of the protocol. The ones that you will often have to deal with are listed below.
GetRequest: A PDU request from a Manager to an Agent requesting the value of specific OID variable.
SetRequest: A PDU request from a Manager to an Agent updating the value of an OID variable.
GetNextRequest: A Manger to an Agent requesting the next element from the current OID variable index.
GetBulkRequest: Similar to the above but in multiple iterations
Response: The acknowledgement from an Agent to a Manager afer the Get, Set, Next and Bulk requests
Trap: Notification from an Agent to a Manager activated after certain conditions are met.

section.formalpara: The notifications.xml and MIB The file is responsible for indicating how a given JMX notification should be transformed into an equivalent SNMP trap. The notification-type attribute indicates the type of JMX notification to transform. Below is an extract from the notifications.xml file:
section.screen: <notification-map-list> <mapping notification-type="jboss.snmp.agent.heartbeat" generic="3" specific="0" enterprise="1.2.3.4.5.6.7"> Â Â Â <var-bind-list wrapper-class="org.jboss.jmx.adaptor.snmp.agent.NotificationWrapperSupport"> Â Â Â Â Â <var-bind tag="a:uptime" oid="1.2.3.4.5.6.7.5"/> Â Â Â Â Â <var-bind tag="a:trapCount" oid="1.2.3.4.5.6.7.6"/> Â Â Â Â Â <var-bind tag="n:message" oid="1.2.3.4.5.6.7.7"/> Â Â Â Â Â <var-bind tag="n:sequenceNumber" oid="1.2.3.4.5.6.7.8"/> Â Â Â </var-bind-list> Â </mapping> </notification-map-list>
section.para:
This notification would catch the "jboss.snmp.agent.heartbeat" notification, and create an SNMP trap with the payload described in each var-bind, according to the var-bind-list wrapper-class. This class defines how such objects are retrieved.
The values contained in generic and specific variables are to identify the traps. the OID in the enterprise variable should be the OID of the object that is emitting this trap. The trap can contain an arbitrary amount of <var-bind>s in its payload. It is important to make sure the <var-bind> tags are properly set in order to get the appropriate returned values.
The <var-bind> element, which is much like the <attribute> element inside attributes.xml, is defined like this: <var-bind tag="a:uptime" oid="1.2.3.4.5.6.7.5"/>
A <var-bind> element has two required attributes, and a single optional attribute, for use by the MIB Generator.

entry.para: Used by the default wrapper class to indicate what value to retrieve.
The OID that should be assigned to the retrieved value.
The SNMP type of this variable binding. Used by the MIB generator

section.para: There are two different actions the MIB generator may take, based on the value of the tag attribute.

entry.para: The OID paired with a tag that has value a:* MUST correspond to an <attirbute> in attributes.xml.
A new MIB Entry is defined for each of these var-binds, with OIDs as defined. They are then included in the notification's definition in the MIB.

note.para: Currently there is only support for scalar object based traps in &PLATFORM_NAME; SNMP adaptor.

section.para: If the tag is n:* or u:*, a new entry in the MIB is defined, using the prefix "jmxNotification" for the name and modifying capitalization for readability. The SYNTAX of this new entry is defined by the type attribute.
A table of additional attributes for the <mapping> element is as follows. All values in the "Importance" column are for the MIB Generator, not the snmp-adaptor.

formalpara.title: Ways of Generating a MIB
formalpara.para: Currently, there are two ways to use the MIB Generator. The first is to use the executable jar with the attributes.xml and notifications.xml files as input. The output file is a MIB that can be named as desired.

The second is to use the maven plugin that will invoke the MIB Generator on given files at compile time, allowing you to have an MIB for your web application which is designed to run on the &PLATFORM_NAME; AS.

section.para: Using the JAR
The jar has a very simple set of commands. They are as follows:

listitem.para: -a : The attributes file to be used, if any.
-n : The notifications file to be used, if any.
-m : The Module Name to be used. This Module Name is how the SNMP manager will identify the definitions in the MIB, it is not done by filename.

section.para: The JAR can be used with both attributes / notifications files, or just the attributes file. It is also possible to use it with just the notifications file, but the tags in such a notifications file must not include a:* tags. It must only contain tags for attributes whose definitions can be generated, such as n:* and u:* tags. The -m and -o flags are required. The -o can include the path you would like to put the final MIB.
Example usage:
section.screen: [thauser@tommycat snmp-adaptor.sar]$ java -jar jboss-snmp-5.1.1.GA-mib-generator.jar -a attributes.xml -n notifications.xml -m JBOSS-AS-VARIA -o ~/.snmp/mibs/TEST.mib
section.para: There is also a Maven Plugin available. Instead of specifying these files on the command line, they are included in the plugin descriptor inside your project's pom.xml. Here's an example of such a descriptor:
